definition.p: LetY be a subset of a topological space X . A pair of open sets \setList{A,B} satisfying A\cap Y\not=\emptyset, B\cap Y\not=\emptyset, Y\subseteq A\cup B, and A\cap B\cap Y=\emptyset is called a disconnection of Y.
A subset of a space for which a disconnection exists is called disconnected; otherwise, the space is called connected.
A set which is both closed and open is said to be clopen.

proposition.p: A pair \setList{A,B} of open sets is a disconnection of Y\subseteq X if and only if \setList{A\cap Y,B\cap Y} is a partition of Y by non-empty clopen sets in the subspace topology.

corollary.p: A space itself is disconnected if and only if it is the union of two disjoint non-empty clopen subsets.

proposition.p: The Euclidean line with a point removed \mb R\setminus\setList{0} is disconnected.

lemma.p: Let \mb R=U\cup V for open sets U,V and let x\in U,y\in V with x\leq y. Then \inf\setBuilder{z\in[x,y]}{z\in V}\in U\cap V.

proposition.p: The Sorgenfrey topology on \mb R is disconnected.

theorem.p: If a subset A of a topological space is connected, then \cl A is connected.

proposition.p: If a subset A of a topological space X is connected and f:X\to Y is continuous, then f[A] is connected.
Let \setList{0,1} have the discrete topology. Then a topological space X is connected if and only if every continuous function f:X\to\setList{0,1} is constant.

theorem.p: If \mc A is a collection of connected subsets of a topological space with \bigcap\mc A\not=\emptyset, then \bigcup\mc A is connected.

definition.p: Suppose for every two points x,y\in A\subseteq X, there exists a continuous function f:[0,1]\to A such that f(0)=x and f(1)=y. Such a space is said to be path connected.

proposition.p: Every path connected space is connected.

exercise.p: Find or create an example of a connected space that's not path connected.
